findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract does not allow non-excluded addresses to transfer tokens initially, but this restriction can be resumed once the contract owner enables them.

findings.title: TUU - Time Units Usage
findings.description: The contract is using arbitrary numbers to form time-related values, decreasing code readability and preventing compiler optimization.

findings.title: RSD - Redundant Struct Declaration
findings.description: The contract declares the `userData` struct to keep track of each user's last buy. Since the struct only contains one property, it could be omitted.

findings.title: RED - Redundant Event Declaration
findings.description: The contract declares events but they are not used in the contract, making them redundant.

findings.title: UF - Unimplented Function
findings.description: A function with no code is a function that has been declared in a contract or interface but has no actual code that executes when the function is called.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: MC - Missing Check
findings.description: The contract is processing variables that have not been properly sanitized and checked that they form the proper shape.

findings.title: RVD - Redundant Variable Declaration
findings.description: The contract declares redundant variables `trade_type` and `minimumWeiForTokenomics` which are not being used in any meaningful way by the contract.

findings.title: UFM - Unused Fee Mechanism
findings.description: The contract declares variables and functions as part of a fee mechanism. However, this mechanism is not being used by the transaction flow.

findings.title: RSF - Redundant Swap Functionality
findings.description: The contract implements a swap functionality but it's redundant since there is no functionality for collecting fees and the contract's balance will always be zero.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract is using variables that initialize them only in the constructor and are not mutated by other functions, but these variables are not defined as `immutable`.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide, which can lead to decreased readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can occur due to conditional statements that are always false, functions that are never called, or unreachable code, making a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and increasing its size and deployment cost.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L18 - Multiple Pragma Directives
findings.description: If the contract includes multiple conflicting pragma directives, it may produce unexpected errors.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
